values.title: Use npm scripts instead of updateGZ3D

content.raw:
It would be more standard to call grunt commands from npm scripts than from our custom `updateGZ3D.sh` bash script. 

Maybe add this to `package.xml`:

~~~
  "scripts": {
    ...
    "build": "cd gz3d/utils grunt build cd ../..",
    "doc": "cd gz3d/utils grunt jsdoc cd ../..",
  },
~~~

Then the usage would be:

~~~
npm run build
npm run doc
~~~

I think we could even call cmake from a script.

There's probably a more elegant way to handle the paths than using `cd` inside the scripts.
content.html:
It would be more standard to call grunt commands from npm scripts than from our custom updateGZ3D.sh bash script.

Maybe add this to package.xml:

  "scripts": {
    ...
    "build": "cd gz3d/utils grunt build cd ../..",
    "doc": "cd gz3d/utils grunt jsdoc cd ../..",
  },

Then the usage would be:

npm run build
npm run doc

I think we could even call cmake from a script.

There's probably a more elegant way to handle the paths than using cd inside the scripts.

content.raw:
Since pull request #133, there are 2 linters in use: ESLint and JSHint.

There is some inconsistency on how we're using them.

*    `npm run update` concatenates `src/*.js` into `gz3d.js` from and then runs JSHint on `gz3d.js`
*    `npm test` runs ESLint on `src/*.js` and then runs tests using `gz3d.js`

I think it would be more coherent if:

*    both linters were run with the same command
*    both linters should run on the same files, either the source files or the built file

Of course, an even cleaner solution would be to get rid of one of the linters.
content.html:
Since pull request #133, there are 2 linters in use: ESLint and JSHint.

There is some inconsistency on how we're using them.

  • npm run update concatenates src/*.js into gz3d.js from and then runs JSHint on gz3d.js
  • npm test runs ESLint on src/*.js and then runs tests using gz3d.js

I think it would be more coherent if:

  • both linters were run with the same command
  • both linters should run on the same files, either the source files or the built file

Of course, an even cleaner solution would be to get rid of one of the linters.

content.raw:
GZIface currently takes an instance of Gui into its constructor, and makes direct calls to it throughout the code.

This prevents Iface from being used without Gui, or with different interfaces and violates the single responsibility principle.

One way of decoupling would be to substitute the direct calls to Gui with global events which are fire by Iface and may be observed by Gui.
content.html:
GZIface currently takes an instance of Gui into its constructor, and makes direct calls to it throughout the code.

This prevents Iface from being used without Gui, or with different interfaces and violates the single responsibility principle.

One way of decoupling would be to substitute the direct calls to Gui with global events which are fire by Iface and may be observed by Gui.

content.raw: Is there a use for them, do we expect them to be called from anywhere besides the costructor? Could their code be moved to the constructor?
content.html: Is there a use for them, do we expect them to be called from anywhere besides the costructor? Could their code be moved to the constructor?

content.html: Pull request #145 started making them independent, after that, we should completely remove the logPlay variable from Gui.

content.raw:
So far, GzWeb has produced a single concatenated file: `gz3d.js`, which contains all the files under the `gz3d/src` folder in alphabetical order. We also produce its minified version.

As we move towards embedding GzWeb into other projects, it would be useful to offer other combinations of files for different use cases.

I propose the following convention:

* `.full` means the file contains all necessary dependencies
* `.iface` means the file contains `gziface`, the websocket interface to the backend
* `.gui` means the file contains `gzgui` and `gzradialmenu`, the jQuery, AngularJS and sprites menus
* The absence of both `.iface` and `.gui` means they're both included - confusing?
* `.min` Minified version, there is one for each file

## Some use cases

### User wants to have control over what dependencies they're including

Include individual `src/gz*.js` files or `gz3d.js` and hand-pick dependencies.

We don't guarantee that a missing dependency will be properly handled though, so for example, if the user doesn't include the `STLLoader` but tries to load an STL file, that will cause an error.

### User wants to embed a simulation scene into their site, but use their own UI elements instead of the ones provided by GzWeb

`gz3d.iface.full.js` - This is introduced on pull request #153

### User wants to use GzWeb as a serverless SDF viewer (issue #107) with their own UI elements

`gz3d.full.js` - That would be what pull request #141 calls `SDFViewer.js`


These are all just ideas, I'm not sold on any of them yet.
content.html:
So far, GzWeb has produced a single concatenated file: gz3d.js, which contains all the files under the gz3d/src folder in alphabetical order. We also produce its minified version.

As we move towards embedding GzWeb into other projects, it would be useful to offer other combinations of files for different use cases.

I propose the following convention:

  • .full means the file contains all necessary dependencies
  • .iface means the file contains gziface, the websocket interface to the backend
  • .gui means the file contains gzgui and gzradialmenu, the jQuery, AngularJS and sprites menus
  • The absence of both .iface and .gui means they're both included - confusing?
  • .min Minified version, there is one for each file

Some use cases

User wants to have control over what dependencies they're including

Include individual src/gz*.js files or gz3d.js and hand-pick dependencies.

We don't guarantee that a missing dependency will be properly handled though, so for example, if the user doesn't include the STLLoader but tries to load an STL file, that will cause an error.

User wants to embed a simulation scene into their site, but use their own UI elements instead of the ones provided by GzWeb

gz3d.iface.full.js - This is introduced on pull request #153

User wants to use GzWeb as a serverless SDF viewer (issue #107) with their own UI elements

gz3d.full.js - That would be what pull request #141 calls SDFViewer.js

These are all just ideas, I'm not sold on any of them yet.

[Fri Dec 22 2017 12:19:26 GMT+0900 (KST)] "GET /favicon.ico" "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/63.0.3239.84 Safari/537.36"

Until recently, GzWeb could only handle resources (models, meshes, textures...) which were served by itself, under the /assets route.

Since pull request #153, it became possible to load resources served by another GzWeb backend, but still relying on the /assets route.

Pull request #149 (i.e. pull request #141) adds a generic way to load models from any URL, the caveat is that the complete list of resources to be used needs to be known before attempting to load the model.

I think that ideally, we would support passing the URL of an SDF file, and automatically discovering the URLs of all resources it needs, similar to how gzclient does it. For example:

sdfparser.addModelPath(<url>);
sdfparser.addModelPath(<another_url>);
sdfparser.loadSdf(<sdf_url>);

content.raw:
* Fix looking up dae texture path, e.g. when testing the collapsed police station, I see that it's trying to get the texture images from: https://staging-api.ignitionfuel.org/1.0/models/29592529-5792-4c98-a049-7bfe1af0f75d/files/meshes/collapsed_police_station_diffuse.jpg. We don't notice this problem in gzweb because the deploy script pre-processes the dae file and updates the texture path to look in `../materials/textures`

* provide a client side material parser

* host the default gazebo media files, i.e. files in `gazebo/media/materials`, somewhere that be downloaded parsed by the material parser, e.g. some models look for `Gazebo/Grey`

* support <include> / nested models

We don't notice this problem in gzweb because the deploy script pre-processes the dae file and updates the texture path to look in ../materials/textures

  • provide a client side material parser

  • host the default gazebo media files, i.e. files in gazebo/media/materials, somewhere that be downloaded parsed by the material parser, e.g. some models look for Gazebo/Grey

  • support <include> / nested models

Our tests are already using ES6, but our source code isn't yet. It would be nice to upgrade so we can use things like `Promise`s.

On pull request #165, I used a promises and arrow functions and:

* Locally disabled jshint so it wouldn't complain
* Changed the uglify script to handle ES6

Does anyone see any problems with this?

content.raw:
A Model who has box geometry link does not spawned, when <size> tag’s value in <box> geometry has white space at the front.

Example

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.4">
    <model name='a_model'>
        <link name='box_shape_linnk'>
            <pose> 0 0 0 0 0 0 </pose>
            <collision name='col_box'>
                <geometry>
                    <box>
                        <size> 1 1 1 </size>
                    </box>
                </geometry>
            </collision>
            <visual name='vis_box'>
                <geometry>
                    <box>
                        <size> 1 1 1 </size> <!-- size value has whitespace at the front-->
                    </box>
                </geometry>
            </visual>
        </link>
    </model>
</sdf>
```

Because before parse the value of <size> tag, value string is splited to \[“ “, size\_x,  size\_y, size\_z, “ “\] when value string contain white space at front.

It occurs when parseSize function split ‘sizeStr’ with ‘\\s\+’regex.

So when trim\(\) was added to remove the space, it was confirmed that the model with the box size containing front of white space could be spawned

```javascript
---  var values = sizeStr.split(/\s+/); 
+++  var values = sizeStr.trim().split(/\s+/);  
```
content.html:
A Model who has box geometry link does not spawned, when <size> tag’s value in <box> geometry has white space at the front.

Example

<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.4">
    <model name='a_model'>
        <link name='box_shape_linnk'>
            <pose> 0 0 0 0 0 0 </pose>
            <collision name='col_box'>
                <geometry>
                    <box>
                        <size> 1 1 1 </size>
                    </box>
                </geometry>
            </collision>
            <visual name='vis_box'>
                <geometry>
                    <box>
                        <size> 1 1 1 </size> <!-- size value has whitespace at the front-->
                    </box>
                </geometry>
            </visual>
        </link>
    </model>
</sdf>

Because before parse the value of <size> tag, value string is splited to [“ “, size_x, size_y, size_z, “ “] when value string contain white space at front.

It occurs when parseSize function split ‘sizeStr’ with ‘\s+’regex.

So when trim() was added to remove the space, it was confirmed that the model with the box size containing front of white space could be spawned

---  var values = sizeStr.split(/\s+/); 
+++  var values = sizeStr.trim().split(/\s+/);

values.title: Which version of gzweb should I use?

content.raw:
Hi there!

I was looking for a guide like there is for **gazebo** and **ROS** matching \([http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=ros\_wrapper\_versions](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials/?tut=ros_wrapper_versions)\):

* **Indigo** matches with **gazebo 2**
* **Kinetic** matches with **gazebo 7**
* **Melodic** matches with **gazebo 9**

But for **gzweb** and **gazebo**

---

 I noticed there are some branches specified with a version number, for example:

* 1.2.0
* 1.3.0
* 1.4.0
* 2.0.0

Is there a recommendation about which version I should use depending on my gazebo version?

Thanks in advance!
